PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Defence and relates to the use of VIP aircraft, is in three parts. Firstly, can the Minister confirm that the use and relocation costs for Royal Australian Air Force VIP aircraft by the honourable member for the Northern Territory, Mr Warren Snowdon, have been in excess of $100,000 in the five months since Mr Snowdon's appointment as Parliamentary Secretary in 1990-including an $18,000 extravagant trip to an electorate commitment at the Tennant Creek Show on 13 July? Secondly, was Mr Snowdon's most recent VIP trip last week, from Sydney to an ethnic conference in Darwin-undertaken when commercial flights were available-in addition to an extra VIP flight to the same conference by the relevant portfolio Minister, Mr Hand? Who accompanied Mr Snowdon and Mr Hand, and were the total return costs of these two parallel flights in excess of $40,000? Thirdly, do the guidelines for the use of VIP aircraft, as previously tabled in the Senate, make any provision for their use by Parliamentary Secretaries? Will the Minister again table the guidelines together with his reasons for approving all VIP flights by Australian Labor Party Parliamentary Secretaries this year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have always said that Senator Tambling's bark is worse than his bite, and he has proven it again today. As anyone would know, it is a common feature of Oppositions, be they Labor or Liberal, to have a ball with VIP flights. We have done it in the past; now the day has come for honourable senators opposite to raise the issue. One of the amazing things about this matter is that some of the car drivers tell Labor Ministers that we are nuts. They say, `When we used to drive the Liberal Ministers they used VIP flights like taxis. We hardly ever pick up you blokes from VIP flights'. What we might have to do is to go through the record and make a comparison between this Government and the previous Government. Then the hypocritical critics on the other side of the chamber will duck for cover.

ANSWER.PARA: How often have I had complaints, as late as Sunday and at other times, about access to VIP flights-that they should be for backbenchers and for everyone else. Yet Senator Tambling, in his normal carping way, raises questions in here about Mr Snowdon. He has used four flights, three times representing another Minister and once to attend a constituency function.

The figures quoted by Senator Tambling are relatively accurate. In regard to the Darwin flight, I understand the problem there was that Mr Snowdon was booked on a commercial flight and that flight was cancelled.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was reinstated.
—It was later reinstated without Mr Snowdon's knowledge and, therefore, that is the explanation for not travelling by commercial flight.
—He went to a dog show.
—Was Senator Walters entered? If she were, she would have won.

ANSWER.PARA: The final point raised by Senator Tambling is, I think, a more serious one. The entitlement of Parliamentary Secretaries to use special purpose aircraft is set out in the entitlements of Parliamentary Secretaries made by prime ministerial statement in April. Senator Tambling asks whether they are in the current guidelines. No, they are not, because they have not been revised recently. I have been looking to revise the guidelines, on a number of bases. One even includes a self-interest in this place as to whether Senator Hill should be entitled to use it.

TALK.START.PARA: —But not to dog shows.

—`But not to dog shows', he says. I will go no further. Also, we have to look at the charging regime to see whether it is different for Falcons compared with other planes. A further problem that concerns some honourable senators in this place is the difficulty of using those aircraft to move backbenchers when no Minister is on board. I am talking about Western Australia, et cetera. I have been considering those guidelines. I have not been rushed into doing it because I have had higher priority areas to look at. But I have that under consideration. When that does occur, I will release those guidelines.

ANSWER.PARA: To sum up: every now and then special purpose aircraft are always open to ridicule from Oppositions. Members of the Opposition get some good brownie points up. Then, when they come into government, they use them as vigorously and rigorously as a government does.

Finally, I wish Senator Tambling well for the next five weeks when he will be floating across overseas first class at taxpayers' expense, staying in all the first class hotels in Europe. I could make derisory comments about that except I know that someone of his diligence will make such a fact finding tour to his own benefit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am pleased that the Minister has acknowledged that the figures I used in my question-the $100,000 and the $40,000-were roughly of the correct order. His comments with regard to my overseas trip, of course, are totally irrelevant to this particular issue. Labor members will be part of that contingent as well.
—Order! The honourable senator will ask his supplementary question.
—The Minister failed to address my second point. I again ask: was Mr Snowdon's most recent visit to Darwin last week in parallel with another VIP flight to the same conference by Mr Hand?

—I understand Mr Hand did go to Darwin to address the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia conference. Obviously he would have left from a different destination. As far as possible one tries to coordinate the times of these sorts of trips and, if it is possible, have one plane do multitasking. That is not always possible, depending on the amount of rotation time staff have been available for. It is frustrating at times. One thinks that one can get a plane to go to Melbourne and then on to Perth and then finds that the tasking arrangements for that plane and the crew on that plane do not allow for that sort of trip. I do not know the exact circumstances in this case as to the crew requirements. I will have a look at it.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Can the Minister give the Senate details of the agreement reached last night at the Jakarta meeting on Cambodia? Does the significance of the agreement mean that the 50-year war in Cambodia and Indo-China may be coming to an end?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt at all that the agreement reached last night in Jakarta by the four Cambodian parties under the joint chairmanship of Indonesia and France, as the co-chairmen of the Paris conference, did represent an enormous breakthrough- unquestionably the most important breakthrough-in the whole gruelling peace process to date. The nature of the achievement is, I think, best appreciated if I were to summarise briefly the main points to emerge in the agreed communique.

ANSWER.PARA: They are as follows: the Cambodian parties accepted in its entirety the framework document laying out the essence of a settlement which had been formulated by the Permanent Five members of the Security Council in a series of meetings over the last six months. Secondly, they indicated their willingness to elaborate that framework into a full-scale comprehensive settlement through the processes of the Paris conference, with there being agreement to reconvene that conference at the earliest possible date.

Thirdly, they established the long-awaited Supreme National Council (SNC)-a group of 12 representative Cambodian individuals possibly to be supplemented by a thirteenth were there to be consensus about the election of a chairman, but constituted right now with 12 members-balanced as follows: six from the Hun Sen Government in Phnom Penh and two from each of the three resistance parties.

The next element in the agreement was that the SNC will operate as the formal embodiment of the independence sovereignty and unity of Cambodia. Next, that the SNC, very importantly, would occupy the United Nations (UN) seat which presently is held, of course, by the resistance coalition including the Khmer Rouge. That is a subject of very great controversy which is now certain to be resolved amicably as a result of this agreement in Jakarta last night.

Finally, and crucially, it was agreed that the SNC, at the time of the signature of the expected comprehensive statement, would delegate to the United Nations, `all powers necessary to ensure the implementation of the comprehensive agreement, including those relating to the conduct of free and fair elections and the relevant aspects of the administration of Cambodia'.

I guess the importance of all this is pretty self-evident to those honourable senators who have been following the peace process closely through all its ups and downs and permutations over the last goodness knows how many years. It is a particularly gratifying achievement for Indonesia, and the Indonesian Foreign Minister, Ali Alatas, in particular, who have led the effort within the region to try to craft an effective, workable, comprehensive settlement, and have done so notwithstanding facing a number of set-backs in unsuccessful meetings of one kind or another, particularly those that had been held in Jakarta previously. It involved a considerable risk, in a sense, to make one more effort to bring the parties together in this way. That risk has proved eminently well-justified and I congratulate the Indonesians, in particular, for their efforts in this respect.

I also want to pay tribute to my own departmental team in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, and the task force that has worked so closely with me over the last year or so in trying to work a way through this particular maze. The result is a gratifying one for Australia, as I do not need to spell out in detail because the Senate will be aware that those elements of the P5 framework document that I have referred to, and the more extended concept of the UN role, is very much the Australian concept that we put on the table last November and have been working away at ever since.

I particularly want to thank my own team for the work they have done and, in particular, single out the Deputy Secretary of my Department, Mike Costello, for what has been a really outstanding diplomatic achievement involving creativity, imagination, stamina and just plain diplomatic skill in shuttling backwards and forwards around the region and internationally over the whole of the last period. There is a long history to be written about the course of these negotiations, but now is not the time to state any of that in detail in public.

Perhaps I should say finally that I am also gratified by Senator Hill's response on the radio this morning. He said it was good news that the settlement had been reached in this way last night. We are particularly glad to have that acknowledgment from Senator Hill given, of course, that it was him--

TALK.START.PARA: —And over the last 12 months.

—No -given that it was Senator Hill who, on 18 July, was widely reported as saying from Cambodia that the search for a comprehensive settlement under the Australian formula had manifestly failed, that there was no possible way of involving all the parties to the conflict in a settlement in an acceptable way, and that we had better start pursuing a different track.
—You've got more faith in the Khmer Rouge then I have.

—I simply say that I am indebted to Senator Hill for his second thoughts in this respect, and I am indebted to him for his being gracious enough to acknowledge the nature of the achievement, in particular the Australian achievement, in his contribution this morning. I seek leave to incorporate into Hansard the full text--
—Not the Red Book?
—No, not the Red Book; the full text of the joint statement of the Jakarta meeting.

ANSWER.PARA: JOINT STATEMENT OF THE JAKARTA MEETING

I. In the exercise of the mandate conferred upon them by the International Conference on Cambodia held in Paris, 30 July-30 August 1989, the two Co-Chairmen convened an informal meeting of the Cambodian parties in Jakarta, 9-10 September 1990. The objective of the Meeting was to ascertain the views of the Cambodian parties on their support and acceptance of the framework of a comprehensive settlement as agreed upon by the Five Permanent Members of the UN Security Council in New York on 28 August 1990 as well as to finalise the formation of the Supreme National Council (SNC).

II. The Cambodian parties accepted the framework document formulated by the Five Permanent Members of the Security Council in its entirety as the basis for settling the Cambodia conflict, and committed themselves, in full cooperation with all other participants of the Paris International Conference on Cambodia (PICC), to elaborating this framework into a comprehensive political settlement through the processes of the PICC.

III. In this context, the Cambodian parties addressed the question of a Supreme National Council of Cambodia, and agreed on the nature and functions of the SNC as stipulated in the P5 document. They specifically agreed as follows:
(a) the SNC is the unique legitimate body and source of authority in which, throughout the transitional period, the independence, sovereignty and unity of Cambodia is embodied;
(b) the SNC is composed of representative individuals with authority among the Cambodian people and reflecting all shades of opinion among them;

(c) the SNC will represent Cambodia externally and occupy the seat of Cambodia at the United Nations, in the UN specialised agencies, and in other international institutions and international conferences;

(d) the SNC at the time of signature of the comprehensive settlement will delegate to the UN all powers necessary to ensure the implementation of the comprehensive agreement, including those relating to the conduct of free and fair elections and the relevant aspects of the administration of Cambodia;
(e) all decisions of the SNC will be made by consensus among its members.
IV. Accordingly, the Cambodian parties agreed to form the SNC with the following composition:
By decision of the two Co-Chairmen and for practical reasons, this list is arranged in alphabetical order instead of in order of age seniority as in the PICC.

The Cambodian parties further agreed to accept H.R.H. Prince Norodom Sihanouk's proposal as contained in his statement of September 8, 1990 that if the 12 members of the SNC so desire, they could elect a Chairman for the SNC, who would, in such case, be the ``13th member'' of the SNC.
V. The SNC is to hold its first session as soon as possible.
VI. The two Co-Chairmen agreed to consult with all the other participating countries of the PICC with a view to reconvening the PICC at the earliest possible date.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to Austel's report on mobile telephones, which stated that in its view where there is a duopoly of only two competitors in a market, monopoly prices are still charged, no real choice is offered to the consumer and there is no incentive to adopt new technologies and minimise costs. The Minister would also have seen that Austel then argued that more competitors produce greater benefits in terms of efficiency, price, product and service. I ask the Minister: Is Austel correct in its economic arguments against duopolies and in favour of greater competition? If so, why is the Australian economy not to get the full benefits of competition in telecommunications?

—For those who address it seriously, the telecommunications issue is a very complex one. There are all sorts of very simple solutions to questions relating to telecommunications policies, such as following the example of the British Government of just selling off British Telecom as it did, which has turned out to be something of a disaster. Yet lemming-like, the Opposition follows down that track.
—It is pretty similar to what you are proposing.

—It is not, because British Telecom was privatised, as Senator Alston well knows. He has advocated the same sort of thing here and he still does. The questions relating to telecommunications policy are enormously complex. As Minister representing the Treasurer, it is not for me to say in here whether Austel was right about a particular comment it made. Certainly the Government is concerned to introduce a greater degree of competition into the telecommunications system. And a lot more competition will be introduced into the telecommunications system. I am not qualified to answer whether Austel was right in its particular comment, because I am not an expert on telecommunications matters.

—My question is directed to you, Mr President. A considerable number of people in this building have upper respiratory tract infections, sinus trouble and, I think, a recent new complaint of sore and red eyes. Indeed, as one advertisement says, `Matter of fact, I've got it now'. The number of people sick means that this building either has an air-conditioning problem or is becoming guilty of the sickbuilding syndrome. Can you tell the Senate what measures are being taken to monitor the air-conditioning and what extra steps could be taken to test alternative ways of providing air care in Parliament House? In particular, can some trial programs be conducted allowing people to open their windows, to let in the sweet, clean air of Canberra?

—I did expect Senator Crowley to ask this question on the previous day of the Senate sittings. Unfortunately, I have not brought the very detailed answer I have for her with me today. I hope to have it at the end of Question Time and incorporate it in Hansard then.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Given the Government's pre-emptive decision on plans to privatise in areas ranging from telecommunications to the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, can the Minister explain, first, what is the purpose of the special Australian Labor Party conference on September 24 and in what ways is it anticipated that the conference could in any way alter the decisions already made by Cabinet? Secondly, how does the Government intend to deal with widespread concern among rank and file party members and the union movement, quite apart from obvious concern in the wider community, about these ideologically driven decisions which are not supported by economic imperatives? Thirdly, is this approach to government decision making about privatisation simply the first step towards further moves in areas already under way and a similar pattern in other policy areas such as income support, rail transport and rural marketing?
—I think that the first two parts of the question are out of order because they dealt with party matters. I would allow the third part of the question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr President. The Australian Labor Party is a big party and has a membership with which it consults on these issues. I understand that the Australian Democrats can do that in a little huddle in their corner over there. They do not have to go through the procedures that we do.

ANSWER.PARA: It is wrong to describe the Cabinet's decision as pre-emptive. What Cabinet has done is express a view about these various matters and it is a view based on very sound policy considerations. In the next few weeks and months we will spell out the ground about public ownership in this country and so-called privatisation. We will find these people very much on the back foot about many of these issues when we spell out the ground which will be followed by the Government in relation to these things.

As the Opposition knows full well, it is very easy to spell out some in-principle policies about various issues. It did that prior to the last two elections. It spelled out what it would do with Medicare. However, when it came to the detail it was confused because it did not have any policies. Governments have to deal with real issues and real policies and the details of those policies. That is why within the Government and the Government Party the debate about telecommunications, for example, has been complex and difficult. We do not retreat from that for a moment because we are not just laying down simple political nostrums, as the Opposition does, on these various issues. We are dealing with real issues which governments have to grapple with.

In so far as Senator Powell's suggestion that the Government is hell bent on some new ideological course is concerned, I inform her that that is not so. Governments, throughout their political lives-this Government has had quite a long one and will continue to have a long one in future-have to continue with the policy development process because circumstances change. I think that the Democrats would be well advised to recognise that. Governments have to be adaptable and flexible in the policies which they develop to meet changed circumstances.

I must say that the use of the word `ideological' in relation to the course upon which this Government has embarked in respect of many of these matters is a total misuse. One knows where we will find the ideology on these issues. `Ideology' is a word which does not appeal to me because ideologies are generally mindless. As I said earlier in answer to this question, the Government has given a lot of careful and thoughtful consideration to these issues. They are not mindless decisions which have been arrived at.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence and concerns the operational roles of Australian naval ships in the Gulf. The Government has indicated previously that the rules of engagement which have been transmitted to our ships may be subject to review. Can the Minister indicate to the Senate whether there has been any such review? If so, what determinations have been made?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Government previously announced the operational roles that had been assigned to the ships, it indicated that they may be subject to change. At its meeting on 30 August 1990, Cabinet noted that there may be some variation arising out of the naval conference of participating nations. That conference has now been held. Consequently, and following appropriate consultation, which included the Leader of the Opposition, our ships have now been sent revised rules of engagement.

ANSWER.PARA: Whilst I am not able to reveal precise details, I can indicate that the variations go to the circumstances under which our ships may engage in halting, boarding and verification of any vessels suspected of breaking the United Nations sanctions. The Australian operational roles have been coordinated with, and understood by, the other participating navies.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer the Minister to the fact that Iraq attempted to make a payment of $1m via a New York bank to the Australian Wheat Board last Monday fortnight for wheat already shipped, but that payment did not proceed because of United States action which has frozen all Iraqi assets in the United States. Does the Government accept that the Australian Wheat Board should be able to accept payment for wheat delivered to Iraq prior to the application of sanctions? If not, will the Government compensate the Australian Wheat Board for failure to receive such payment considering that the Wheat Board has already postponed in part a scheduled payment for September?
—I am not familiar with the particular facts of that matter. It would require a far lesser mind than mine to lay down any general procedures about that, but I will obtain an answer.
—Lesser, I meant. I will endeavour to obtain an answer and give it to the honourable senator as soon as possible.

—My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia. Can the Minister advise the Senate of the impact of a broad-based consumption tax on residents living in northern Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In short, the imposition of a broad-based consumption tax at point of sale, which is the only effective way, and the only administratively and financially responsible way one can implement such a tax, would be disastrous on people living in northern Australia. It is generally understood, and it has certainly been understood ever since I started to follow this consumption tax debate some years ago, that one of the inherent difficulties with a broad-based consumption tax is that it impacts proportionately on low-income earners much more savagely than it does on higher income earners for the simple reason, obviously, that low-income earners spend a far higher proportion of their income-in some cases all of it-on goods and services that attract a consumption tax. But what is not generally recognised and has not been part of the debate that I have heard, and certainly has not been raised by any member of the National Party that I have noted, is that the tax impacts far more severely on people who live away from the major urban areas than it does on their city cousins.
—What have you done about zone rebates?

—Ha, ha! I am glad to hear that interjection concerning zone rebates and sales tax on freight because, as Senator Tambling would well know, it shows one of the huge holes in the Opposition's taxation policy. Senator Tambling would well know that for years there has been a debate in which he and I and others have participated, in northern Australia, in trying to remove the imposition of sales tax on the freight component of goods. I have had numerous briefings over the years with taxation officers in Darwin and in Canberra and one of the difficulties is that the sales tax regime is already very complicated and the argument put by the Australia Taxation Office, which is valid, is that if one starts introducing a further administrative layer of extracting the freight component-I have to say this in fairness-and in many cases the alleged freight component, from the cost of goods before one imposes tax on it, it would become very quickly an administrative nightmare and would cost a fortune to implement. I have to say through clenched teeth that there is a great deal of validity to that argument.

ANSWER.PARA: It is very difficult to counter that argument with a straight face because it is substantially true. It points up one of the huge holes in the nonsense that is currently being run in the bush by the National Party on its policy for a broad-based consumption tax. For everyone outside a major city the difficulty is that currently we have an imposition of having to pay sales tax on the freight component of goods. With a broad-based consumption tax at point of sale, people have to pay a tax on the freight component of everything. I might add that services such as haircuts also attract the tax. The National Party has put out a piece of arrant nonsense saying that there will be exemptions from the tax.

The difficulty is that people will be paying consumption tax on meat, milk, bread and other staple items which are often produced in the area and which currently do not attract tax on the freight component because they are produced locally. But the consumption tax will apply to everything, particularly the freight component which has to be applied at the point of sale.

We cannot responsibly do what the Leader of the National Party is now saying publicly wink, wink, nudge, nudge in the bush-that is, that his Party will provide a range of exemptions. As soon as that is done-and not one single person can deny this-we run into exactly the same problem that we have with the imposition of sales tax on freight. As soon as they start--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to the fact that the Minister is ranging far and wide and giving us his personal view on a consumption tax. He is not addressing the question. I ask you to call him to order. We on this side of the chamber have a policy against long answers.
—We give in then.
—Order! The answer is allowable. But I must remind Senator Collins that it is becoming a very long answer.

—I am pleased that the Opposition has a policy on long answers because it must be the only policy it actually has. The difficulty is that as soon as one starts advocating a range of exemptions from this tax, one makes the collection of the tax so expensive that one cannot then justify it. Further to that, the Leader of the National Party in the Federal Parliament has put up an even more absurd suggestion in which he has said that the Opposition will exempt farmers from the tax. Could honourable senators image any government trying to single out one component of the community and saying that it is exempted from the tax?

ANSWER.PARA: The difficulty with that proposition is that not only can it not be fairly or equitably done but, by exempting anything from a broad-based consumption tax, one will load up the taxation component of everything else contained within the tax. In short, Mr President--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Collins, you are turning this into a debate.
—Indeed, it should be, Mr President.
—Well, it is not.
—In conclusion, Mr President,--
—Mr President, on the point of order: the Minister is clearly defying your ruling.
—He is not. I have told Senator Collins that he is debating the matter and he stated, `In conclusion'.
—In conclusion, Mr President, the introduction of a consumption tax on the basis that the Opposition has suggested would, in a word, be unworkable.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SOUTH-EASTERN FORESTS OF NEW SOUTH WALES: LOGGING

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to the lengthy media release made by Senator Cook, in his then capacity as Minister for Resources, dated 13 July 1989 wherein he said that the New South Wales and Commonwealth governments have agreed to implement promptly the joint scientific committee's decision on logging in the south-eastern forests of New South Wales. Will the Minister confirm that the joint scientific committee's report satisfactorily addresses the environmental concerns in the area and, if so, when will the Government uphold its clearly stated undertaking to promptly implement the plan?

—As much as I have always been deeply impressed by Senator Cook's press releases, I do not actually carry all of them around in my head, nor in my folder. I cannot recall all of the words that were in this one. But, being a charitable person by nature, I will accept Senator Bishop's word that it contained what it was supposed to have said. If it said that we would deal with that scientific report promptly, I suppose it gets down to the definition of `prompt'. We have had one preliminary report from Ministers on this matter; another is expected within the next few days. Negotiations will be held with the New South Wales Government on Thursday. After that, Cabinet will be briefed and the Government will make its decision.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The focus of the question was: would the Minister confirm that the report satisfactorily addresses the environmental concerns in the area? I suggest that the people who are demonstrating outside this Parliament would feel that the word `promptly' has some specific meaning.

—It is a matter for the Government, not just any individual Minister to determine these things. My opinion is not relevant. It is a matter for Cabinet and all these very impressive colleagues of mine on either side who will help us make the decision.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is it a fact that industrial relations is an area of Commonwealth-State arrangements where the potential exists for greater administrative and other forms of efficiency? Can the Minister advise the Senate what reforms the Government considers are possible on this issue? Can he also advise what progress has been achieved in bringing greater simplification into Commonwealth-State industrial relations arrangements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with the observations that Senator Foreman has made in his question-that industrial relations systems in Australia is one of the areas in which considerable efficiencies can be achieved. Indeed, the Prime Minister, in his now famous speech to the National Press Club, identified industrial relations as a possible area of constitutional reform. I notice that, in his reply address, the Premier of New South Wales, Nick Greiner, also targeted industrial relations as an important area of reform, and other States have made similar noises. We await now the constitutional meeting between the Premiers and the Prime Minister in October to see how far that one can go.

ANSWER.PARA: To answer the detail of the question raised by Senator Foreman-already industrial relations Ministers in all of the States and Territories have resolved on a course of action which will enable significant reforms to be made, whatever the outcome of the constitutional issue might be. At a meeting of the Ministers for Labour Advisory Council in New Zealand in April this year, all of the State Ministers, Territory Ministers and I agreed that they would nominate the heads of their tribunals and I would appoint to the Federal Commission, the heads of their tribunals as deputy presidents, that they would amend their State Industrial Relations Acts and enable me to nominate deputy presidents of the Federal Commission to be appointed to their benches in all of the States.

In addition to that-which brings, if you like, at the arbitrational level, a blending of the Federal-State relationship-there have now been talks between my Department and the departments of industrial relations in the States about using common court room facilities, operating out of the same registry, using the same chambers, the same libraries and the same electronic information retrieval systems, and the integration, at a working level, of the operations of industrial relations around Australia.

This is a reform in which the States see some cost savings, I might say, but that is not the main motivator for them. At a time in which there is a congruence about industrial relations in all States-and I include New South Wales as well with respect to the management of the system- they see it as desirable to achieve as much of a cooperative working relationship as is possible. The model will, I think, bring about a national system within a federal constitutional framework, and that will be a significant achievement. I think it will be a step along the way to an eventual unitary system when the constitutional debate about powers might finally be determined.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. What, if anything, does the Government intend to do to overcome one of the problems of the Trade Practices Commission as expressed by its chairman, Professor Baxt, that the monetary penalty provisions of the Trade Practices Act are so inadequate for major defaulters, such as Toshiba, that the Commission determined not to prosecute Toshiba in exchange for an undertaking from Toshiba not to do it again?

—This question may have been more appropriately addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I do not know the answer to the question but I shall obtain one as quickly as possible. I totally concur with the desirability of the Trade Practices Act being more effective than perhaps it has been. I sympathise with the spirit of the question and will obtain an answer as soon as I can.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister because the issue covers a number of portfolios. I refer to the August overall unemployment figure of 7 per cent and, sadly, far more than double that unemployment rate for youth. As this figure compares with a rate of 5.7 per cent in August last year, would the Government agree that we in Australia are in an unemployment crisis? Has the Government specifically considered the causes of the high level of unemployment, including the hidden unemployment that is not reflected by those latest figures?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course the Government is concerned about the increased level of unemployment which has particularly become manifest in the past two months. It is fair to say that the achievements of this Government in respect of employment have been extraordinarily good over the life of the Government, having regard to what we inherited. The reason for that is that until recently there has been steady growth in the Australian economy. The current increased levels of unemployment are undoubtedly due to the fall-off in demand in the domestic economy, which at the moment is very marked. That, as I have said, is having significant effects on employment.

ANSWER.PARA: The anticipations in the Budget were that we would see a slack demand and the consequences of that in the second half of this calendar year. In terms of what the Budget has to say, we would expect some improvement in that situation in the first half of calendar year 1991. One hopes that that improvement will be obtained by improvement in export performance which the Budget predicts-that is to say, the growth in the economy, which is expected to be 2 per cent, is largely predicated on growth in exports.

Senator Harradine also asked me about what he called hidden unemployment. I am not in a position to comment about that in an expert way. I shall try to obtain an answer to that part of the question. One of the difficulties about hidden unemployment is that often it is well hidden and one cannot make any observation about it for that reason. I shall endeavour to obtain an answer on that matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Defence. It arises out of a question which he was asked earlier in Question Time by Senator Loosley. As I understood the Minister's answer, the previous rules-I do not know whether strictly they are rules of engagement; they are rather broader than that, and were laid down by Senator Gareth Evans as `identification, contact, interrogation and warning'-are now to be extended to stopping and boarding. I ask the Minister, was that change prompted in any way by a request based on some experience by a captain of one of our warships in the Gulf? Does it mean that our ships can now use force to stop in the course of any warning operation, and does this not suggest that the original rules laid down by the Government a la Senator Gareth Evans were too constrictive?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The main criterion, of course, at any time is operational effectiveness, Senator Durack. The rules of engagement, as announced by me today and sent to the ships yesterday, were not at the request of captains of the ships, because they were at least constructed, if not approved, long before the ships got into the deployment area. They basically arise out of the sanction given by the United Nations resolution 665, which allows the use of minimum force. I think the honourable senator also asked whether this means that some force can be employed by the Australian ships. The answer is yes.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Evans did announce, because he was the first person asked about it, the four previous criteria of operations. These three new ones are consistent with what has been adopted by the United States, by France, by Great Britain, by most members of the Western European Union, if not all, and presumably down the track by other nations. There was a lot of effort put in at the naval conference to make sure that all the rules of engagement were consistent with each other and fully understood by each other. I am happy to report that that conference was a remarkable success.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence. How many naval technicians have been sent to the Gulf region to support the Royal Australian Navy forces there? I also ask whether or not these men constitute ground forces. Could the Minister describe their role and function? I further ask whether there are plans to send more technicians to join the men already there. If so, how many? Are there also any other Australian Defence Force personnel being sent in any other capacity which could be construed as ground forces? Is it true that the Minister was not consulted before the decision was made to send these naval technicians to the Gulf region? Will the Minister be consulted about further deployments? Which other naval vessels are preparing for operations in the Gulf region, either in addition to the current contingent or in replacement of it? Finally, I ask whether the Australian Government has any plans to increase the size or change the nature of the Australian deployment in the Gulf area.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have a small number of naval personnel who have been placed in the Middle East to provide logistical support to our ships. These personnel do not constitute ground forces. There are no plans at present to send additional logistic personnel to the Middle East. There is no intention to commit Australian ground forces to the Middle East. A few Australian exchange personnel have been permitted to deploy with the United States and United Kingdom units to the Middle East for the sake of operational effectiveness of those units. There is no way that their presence could be construed as an Australian commitment of ground forces.

ANSWER.PARA: I was fully consulted concerning the deployment of the logistics team, and will of course be fully consulted about any other aspect of Australian deployment to the Gulf region, whenever it may arise. There is no intention to increase the number of Australian naval ships deployed in the Gulf region. Plans are being developed to replace the current task group when its rotation is completed.

The Government has decided to send a small number of medical support personnel to the Gulf region to provide for any medical contingencies for the task force personnel which may arise. The Government has no plans to increase or change the deployment to the Gulf area, other than that which I announced when answering Senator Loosley. I might add that the medical team will be serving on a hospital ship in the Gulf region.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW ZEALAND: TAX DISINCENTIVES TO TRADE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate in his various capacities, and particularly in his capacity as representing the Treasurer. I refer to the needed removal of the trans-Tasman business restrictions under closer economic relations (CER) with New Zealand and the creation of a level playing field between the two countries. My question is: what steps is the Government taking to remove the tax disincentives to trade, given the disparities in corporate tax rates and the differences in jurisdictions relating to tax credits for tax paid in the other country?

—As I recall it, that matter was discussed by officials during the visit of Mr Palmer, the then Prime Minister of New Zealand, to Australia six or seven weeks ago. All I can say is that that question is under examination, as all aspects of CER relating to business regulation and so on have to be. What the outcome of those considerations will be it is too early to say.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. What action has the Minister taken to resolve the dilemma being faced by the Australian carpet wool producers cooperative, Carpet Wool Marketers? Is the Minister aware of the existence of significant forward sales which the cooperative cannot meet while growers remain uncertain about their liability to or freedom from the wool levy? When will the Government stop procrastinating on this issue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can tell Senator Bell that the wool tax, which I think he has referred to as the wool levy, is required by legislation to be paid on all shorn wool, including medullated and other coarse wools suitable for carpet manufacture. The carpet wool growers have made representations seeking exemption from the price support component of the wool tax because they believe that the current 18 per cent tax particularly affects them. Carpet wools are bought by carpet manufacturers scoured and blended rather than in the greasy form. Carpet wool growers have established their own cooperatives to undertake these processes and prepare their wool for the Australian market. The growers themselves support these cooperatives through a 6 per cent levy. Carpet wool growers are therefore currently paying 24 per cent in taxes and levies on wool of $2.50 to $3 a kilo in value. I should add that as some 90 per cent of the carpet wools used in Australia are imported, the Australian grown carpet wool is import replacing in nature.

ANSWER.PARA: The Wool Council of Australia-and the honourable senator may know this-passed a resolution at Roma recently that the Australian Wool Corporation investigate tax exemption for carpet wool. Both the Wool Council and the Wool Corporation have now advised that they do not support exemption of carpet wools on the grounds that exemptions result in inequities at the margins and it is inappropriate to distinguish wools on the grounds of end use, and that any exemption would create an undesirable precedent. They are the views of both the Wool Council and the Wool Corporation.

This issue, I am advised by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, is complex and obviously has implications for wool marketing arrangements in general. The Minister is giving close consideration to the cases put forward by the carpet wool growers, the Wool Council and the Corporation. He anticipates that he will be in a position shortly to give a decision on the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister for Social Security to the latest Australian Bureau of Statistics figures showing that the seasonally adjusted level of youth unemployment in Australia has jumped over the last six months by almost one-third from 15.4 per cent to 20.3 per cent-the worst level for three years. I ask the Minister: What level of youth unemployment-that is, among those between 15 and 19 years old-is incorporated in the Government's Budget forecast for unemployment benefit payments this financial year? What percentage of the 32 per cent budgeted rise in unemployment benefit is forecast to go to unemployed youth?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Baume would be aware, the Treasurer on Budget night indicated that the Government expected unemployment to rise, so that is not any great shock or secret.
—It is, if you find yourself unemployed.
—You dumped 270,000 out in 12 months in 1982.

—I was about to get to that, but I thank the Minister. To repeat myself, the Treasurer indicated on Budget night that unemployment was expected to rise and would rise certainly during the first half of this year. That rise in unemployment, however, will not be a permanent one and we hope that it will begin to come back very quickly after that.
—After what?

—After that initial period in which it rises, which I think the Treasurer indicated would be the first half of the financial year. I hope that after that it will begin to come down. As far as youth unemployment is concerned, quite obviously if there is to be a rise in unemployment as a whole there will be a rise in unemployment amongst youth, particularly since they, as some of the most inexperienced workers, will be among the first to go if managers lay people off. So it is not unexpected.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the rise in unemployment benefit, obviously if there are more unemployed more money will be spent on unemployment benefit. In terms of the actual percentage of money for 15 and 19-year-olds, I do not know but I will find out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I specifically asked what percentage of the 32 per cent increase in unemployment benefit would be going to unemployed youth. I also specifically asked what level of unemployment is implicit in the Government's forecast unemployment benefit level. The Minister agreed to get information on the second part of my question for me. I am asking the Minister to get information on the first part of my question. In the circumstances, as the Minister has to find out the information, is it reasonable to ask whether the Minister was not in fact in possession of that knowledge when his Department made its assessments about what sort of assistance should go to unemployed youth this year in view of the enormous rise in unemployment as a result of the Government's policies?

—I am sure Senator Baume is aware that for those figures to go into the Budget requires agreement between departments. Obviously the Treasury and my own Department were in consultation about the figures and came up with the result for Budget night. I indicated to the honourable senator that I will endeavour to get a break-up of the figures in terms of the percentage of those between 15 and 19 years old being paid unemployment benefit. Most of the other figures to which the honourable senator has referred are actually in the Budget Papers. If there are any extra figures that I need to get for the honourable senator as a result of the question, I will do so. But I do not think there are.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is it a fact that Australia has now ratified International Labour Organisation (KO) Convention 159 which establishes international standards for the employment and rehabilitation of workers with disabilities? In light of the specific initiatives for people with disabilities outlined in the Budget paper entitled New Opportunities for People with Disabilities, what are the main implications for wages for people with disabilities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —ILO Convention 159 is properly entitled Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment (Disabled Workers) Convention. It is a convention adopted by the ILO in 1983. The ILO, of course, is a subagency of the United Nations which was inherited by the United Nations from the League of Nations of which Australia was a foundation member. It is tripartite in nature.

ANSWER.PARA: To answer the first part of Senator Zakharov's question, the Australian Government adopted ILO Convention 159 on 7 August this year. The adoption followed consultation with the particular States and Territories and with employer organisations and trade unions through the National Labour Consultative Council. The convention has been adopted and ratified by 30 countries, including the Netherlands, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland, Denmark, Austria and both East and West Germany, which may soon be trading under the same banner.

Upon ratification, countries are required to adopt a policy on vocational rehabilitation and employment for the disabled; to consult with employers, unions and disabled organisations about how that is to be implemented; to provide vocational guidance, training and placement in employment, and for other related services for the disabled; to ensure suitably qualified staff to provide those services; and to ensure that Australian law and practice comply with the convention requirements-that is to say, the adoption of such a convention commits Australia to observe international standards in dealing with rehabilitation and employment for the disabled. That is consistent with this Government's enviable record on social justice.

To go to the second part of Senator Zakharov's question-there has been a long process, beginning in 1988, firstly with an interdepartmental committee entitled the Disability Work Force. That Committee considered how income support could be best rendered and how to encourage, in particular, the rehabilitation of the disabled. It looked at labour market programs to support their needs, at their particular employment, training and education requirements and at how they could best be involved in community activities. The Budget paper referred to by Senator Zakharov comes from a report from the task force.

To encourage the participation of disabled workers, there is now more work to be done on examining the wages system. My Department is working directly with the departments of the States and other departments of the Commonwealth, as well as with unions and employer organisations, on what appropriate wages policy should apply consistent with national wage fixing principles and the need to ensure that disabled workers are properly remunerated so that they are useful and valuable members of the work force and gain self-esteem through employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier in the year-I think it was in May-Senator Campbell asked me a question about the Commonwealth expenditure on the High Court challenge on the Corporations Act. I have the following answer: The expenditure incurred by the Commonwealth totalled approximately $22,500 most of which consisted of counsel's fees. Although costs were awarded by the High Court against the Commonwealth, the challenging States have not, so far as we are aware, sought payment to date.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time I was asked a question by Senator Crowley concerning the air-conditioning in Parliament House. I have a detailed answer and, with the concurrence of the Senate, I will incorporate it in Hansard. I would also point out to Senator Crowley that I am still receiving complaints from individual senators.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Crowley has asked about an investigation of the air conditioning in the building. In particular she would like alternative forms of air conditioning investigated ie. occupants opening windows in their office.
I have been advised by the JHD that
- Air conditioning system in Parliament House is maintained to the highest standards exceeding the Australian standard requirements.
- Temperature is more precisely controlled than normal buildings, generally between 21 c and 22 c in accordance with individual requirements.
- Humidity comfort zone is internationally recognised as 20% to 60% . Parliament House is operated in the upper segment of this range at all times generally between 45% and 55%

- The code requirements indicate that at least 10% fresh air is required. Dependent on weather conditions the Parliament House is currently set at a minimum of 20 rising to total fresh air when ambient conditions allow
- The air filters and plenums are regularly maintained to minimise dust and other contaminants
- A detailed and comprehensive program is undertaken monthly to ensure against bacterial growths
- The quality of water in the system is monitored daily
- To further ensure the quality of air, tests are currently being arranged with ANUTECH to confirm the absence of particular matter and noxious gasses in the delivered air.

The chief engineer of the JHD advises the building design is for a totally comprehensive centralised air conditioning system. The opening of any window would cause severe discomfort for all other occupants of that wing.
Further the energy consumption of the building would rise dramatically with significant additional costs to the Parliament.

It has been noted that such complaints as mentioned by Senator Crowley are more prevalent on resumption after extended breaks, as acclimatisation to Canberra is required. This effect is obviously exacerbated in spring with the increase in pollen in the air.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Matters have come to the attention of the Opposition that cause us great concern in relation to the procedures for reference of Bills to committees. Certain practices that are being adopted by committees, we believe, if continued, will defeat the objectives of the reforms that Parliament agreed to in December. I should say that Senator Robert Ray and Senator Powell have indicated a willingness to discuss these matters but, since I spoke to Senator Robert Ray, further matters have been brought to my attention. I simply want to put them on the record to give the Government the opportunity to think about them.

SPEECH.PARA: The first is a motion that has been passed, I understand, by at least two committees that the standing committee, when it receives a Bill from this chamber, in fact, operates as if it was the Committee of the whole; in other words, that a set procedure be in existence for all considerations on that basis, that witnesses not be called, that senators not have the opportunity to examine witnesses, et cetera.

I remind the Government that the sessional orders were silent on how the standing committees would deal with the Bills that were referred to them, but reference to the report of the Committee of the Senate, which was almost wholly adopted, and the guidance of the Clerk in this matter, make it clear that the intention was that each committee would examine each Bill and determine the best way of handling that Bill according to all the circumstances relating to that Bill. Some Bills could clearly be dealt with expeditiously, but some- such as, from my experience, the war crimes legislation and Bills of that nature-would require a very detailed consideration, including the calling of public evidence and a full examination.

The first point I want to put to the Government to consider is whether it might reconsider this practice-which, I presume, has originated from the leadership-that each of the committees adopt this rather rigid form which, as I said, would defeat the objectives of the new system.

The second point that is causing us concern is that we have the strong belief that, in these circumstances, all senators-any senator-should have the right to attend a standing committee and, no doubt with leave which would be given by that committee, to participate in the debate. If we are going to try to avoid a duplication of debate, that seems to us to be necessary. I have to acknowledge that these orders that have been adopted by two committees do give that right.

However, I am advised that a number of my colleagues have been refused the right to appear and participate in committee considerations of Bills that have already taken place in the last few days. That is wrong. I would like the Government to consider the attitude that it is adopting in this.

The third and last matter I raise is that, if this system is to work, the Bills should be considered on the day set aside by the Senate for their consideration. I understand that some committees have brought forward their hearings. This may or may not be convenient for committee members, but it is certainly not convenient for other honourable senators who wish to participate. They simply would not be aware that the matter is to be dealt with on that occasion.

I raise these matters because they are of serious concern to us. We want this new practice to work. We want it to result in a better use of Senate time, in a more thorough examination of Bills and ultimately in better law-making.

I bring these matters to the Government's attention. I hope that when we come to talk about them tomorrow the Government might have given some consideration to the practices it presumably is recommending.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Senator Hill has raised three matters. I think that the second and third matters can be dealt with fairly expeditiously. It is essential that those committees meet on the days set aside, so that everyone then has full knowledge of them. It would be like not telling anyone when the Estimates Committees are on. Whilst I might regard it as a good idea, I would never contemplate it. As to other honourable senators turning up, I always thought that that was part of it.

SPEECH.PARA: The nub of the problem is where we draw the line rather than which extreme committee position we take. If it had been suggested to me that this new committee system envisaged the full circus of witnesses, et cetera, I would never have gone along with it. Honourable senators know how hard it is to get a resolution of legislation. We always thought that promptness was the key to making this work; that matters could be referred and a result achieved. The moment we bring in witnesses we have to give two weeks public notice that we will have hearings on a particular matter. We will blow Bills out by six, eight or 10 weeks. Probably we should have focused on this at the time we adopted the position, but we did not.

I know that the Clerk has put his views forward. I intensely disagree with that approach. It is a legitimate approach, but I happen to disagree with it from a Government point of view. All I can say is that in the next day or two the Government will be happy to sit down with the relevant people to discuss this to see whether we can come to an agreement as to how we should proceed. We prefer to do that with the unanimity of the Senate and not try to use raw numbers to impose our views. We make that quite clear.

However, at this stage I foreshadow that what has been espoused by the Clerk's guidelines is more a select committee role. If it has to go that far and if legislation is that important, that legislation should go to a select committee and not a legislation committee, otherwise, although it might be fun for two years or however long we are in power, at the moment those opposite win office, and if the same applies to them, they will find it immensely frustrating not only having the draftsman slowing down legislation and all the rest of the procedures but also having the legislation bottling up in the committee and making its timeliness impossible to achieve.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wouldn't you put a reporting date on when you referred the Bills?
—I did commend a committee once for meeting the reporting date; but only one so far.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Australian Democrats share Senator Hill's concerns. We believe that the new procedures should envisage each Bill being dealt with by each committee on its merits. We certainly would not expect that every Bill, certainly even the majority of Bills, be dealt with in the lengthy way anticipated by Senator Robert Ray. It will be the occasional Bill on which we may seek public input.

SPEECH.PARA: Contrary to what Senator Ray has indicated, it may well be that dealing with Bills in that way may very significantly cut down the time required for the Committee stages when we come back into the Committee of the Whole in the Senate. I draw attention to the way in which the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission legislation took over 40 hours during its Committee stage in this chamber. Had that been dealt with by a committee, it may well have spent much less time in the chamber and been dealt with quite quickly by the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I rise to speak because the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, Senator Childs, might get a letter from me this afternoon. I did not know that this discussion was going to take place and I do not know the Clerk's guidelines: I do not know of the existence of the Clerk's guidelines. I feel that I should mention this matter now for the benefit of the Chairman.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter refers to the Patents Bill. I had some questions to ask of officers of the Patent, Trade Marks and Designs Offices. In my letter I ask that those officers attend the Committee so that we can ask them questions about statements that they have made and which I want to have clarified if I am to consider whether or not to proceed with amendments to the Patents Bill which would prevent the granting of patents for human cells. I raise the matter now so that it does not come as a bombshell later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-We welcome the remarks of the Australian Democrats because I think they indicate the approach that we desire to take, and that is not, as Senator Ray might otherwise apprehend, a determination to have as many Bills as possible dealt with at exhaustive length by the various legislative and standing committees.

SPEECH.PARA: What we have in mind is that from time to time there will be Bills that deserve thoroughgoing attention and that will necessitate the calling of witnesses and probably a range of other means of examination. But all that can be accomplished much more expeditiously through the existing mechanism than by setting up a select committee. I would have thought we should be at pains to avoid having to go through that rigmarole every time we confront a Bill that perhaps those of us who might form the majority on the matter decide ought to be referred out.

The present system, if approached sensibly-I am sure that we have a commitment to seeing it used sparingly but effectively-should mean that the matters can be dealt with much more quickly. Certainly, we can make use of the time saving that is involved in having more than one committee sitting at the same time, but we can also make use of those specialist committees to address particular issues. I hope that the Manager of Government Business in the Senate, Senator Robert Ray, will reconsider this matter in light of the remarks that have been made.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I think that the references to the guidelines in this debate have been somewhat mixed up. I am informed that the report of the select committee was that each committee would determine how it would deal with such Bills.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Animal Patenting
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Australian Senate.

The undersigned citizens of Australia, and custodians of the Earth, oppose the patenting of animals, and the processes for altering them. Animal patents would *reduce biodiversity, *compromise animal welfare, *concentrate ownership of breeding stock, and *allow companies to appropriate the fruit of centuries of selective breeding. We note with concern that many applications for animal patents have been lodged with the Australian Patents Office and without your intervention they may soon be approved.
Please take all possible steps immediately to ensure that:
1. The Patents Office rejects all existing applications for animal patents and declines to accept any more.
2. The Senate amends the Patents Bill 1989 to prohibit the patenting of animals.
We pray that all members of the Australian Senate will act on this petition.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Coulter (from 705 citizens), Kernot (from 103 citizens), Lees (from 49 citizens), McLean (from 786 citizens) and Spindler (from 491 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Air Landing Fee: New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament:

This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the proposed air landing fee for regional and commuter airlines landing at Sydney Mascot Airport during peak times discriminates severely against people in rural Australia and will force many airlines to either revise their schedules, cancel flights or increase passenger fares to cover this additional financial impost of the Federal Labor Government. This will result in less accessibility for country businessmen and travellers alike, will increase the costs of business for rural people and threatens the viability of many smaller airlines who provide valuable services to rural towns. We therefore call on the Federal Government to abolish all plans for the introduction of this discriminatory fee and allow commuter airlines to continue to provide their full range of services to towns throughout New South Wales.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telephone Directory: Western Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Since the introduction of three (3) regional West Australian telephone directories there has been a constant demand from users to revert to a consolidated country directory which is convenient to all users.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled urge the Minister for Communications to direct Telecom to recognise the requirement of rural West Australians and revert to a single consolidated country telephone directory.

PETITION.TITLE: Environmental Bill of Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate assembled:
The Humble Petition of certain Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That there is urgent need for the United Nations to adopt an Environmental Bill of Rights using the 1987 Report by the World Commission on Environment and Development.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament pass an `Environmental Bill of Rights', therefore giving Australia a leading role in environmental protection.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Shark Bay Region
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strongly oppose the proposed World Heritage listing of the Shark Bay Region in Western Australia, either partially or in its entirety, believing that all conservation values of the Shark Bay region will be fully protected under the Shark Bay Region Plan, developed over three years by conservation authorities; and we respectfully request the Parliament and Government to remove the threat of World Heritage listing for Shark Bay by making a firm decision not to proceed with any further consideration of it.
Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the honourable senators will oppose the World Heritage listing of either a part or the whole of the Shark Bay Region.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: States Grants Schools Assistance Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament.
The Petition of the undersigned shows:

That the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act 1988 includes legislation, Part III-Changes to Non-Government Schools and New Non-Government Schools, designed to inhibit the establishment, growth and development of these schools in Australia by the imposition of restrictive provisions in the areas of funding, enrolments and approval criteria.
Your petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:

Reconsider the application and implications of this legislation in the light of justice, equity and freedom of choice for parents and have the unfair sections (Section 8 (2), 8 (15) and (11)) repealed.
And you petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
(1) They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
(2) They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian crosses, represents the nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its place in space;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901 and each point depicting a State and the Territories of the Commonwealth.
(3) They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
(4) They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
(5) They are certain that any change to its form or to its acceptance as the sole Australian Flag will produce division in the Australian community.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should ensure that the existing Australian National Flag should remain sacrosanct from change and remain the sole national flag.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Papua New Guinea and Bougainville
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned participants of the 1990 ASPAC conference for disarmament, security and co-operation in the Asia-Pacific region call upon the Australian government:

to seek the agreement of the Papua New Guinea government to lift the blockade which deprives our Bougainvillean neighbours of urgently needed medicines, food and fuel supplies, and splits Bougainvillean families;
to encourage the PNG government to uphold its democratic principles by safeguarding the human rights of Bougainvilleans;
to encourage the PNG government to seek a negotiated political settlement to resolve the crisis;
to enlist the active involvement of the International Commission of the Red Cross and the United Nations World Food Program in supplying relief and humanitarian assistance to Bougainville;
to grant refugee status to Bougainvilleans stranded in Australia by the blockade;
to offer assistance for the reconstruction of Bougainville's destroyed villages on a scale comparable to Australia's heightened military training program in PNG.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium: Mining and Export
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Apartheid in South Africa
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament.
The Petition of the undersigned shows:
